summary: Mathilda (Natalie Portman) is only 12 years old, but is already familiar with the dark side of life: her abusive father stores drugs for corrupt police officers, and her mother neglects her. Léon (Jean Reno), who lives down the hall, tends to his houseplants and works as a hired hitman for mobster Tony (Danny Aiello). When her family is murdered by crooked DEA agent Stansfield (Gary Oldman), Mathilda joins forces with a reluctant Léon to learn his deadly trade and avenge her family's deaths.

On paper, Leon: The Professional sounds like any other film centered around a hitman – action, killings and plenty of assorted violence. Leon (Jean Reno) is the soft-spoken but deadly "cleaner", a cold-blooded killer with a strict code of ethics.  Mathilda is the twelve-year old neighbor whose dysfunctional family has been killed as the result of a drug dispute by a corrupt cop (Gary Oldman).  The three main characters all have a depth that far exceeds that of characters in similar films in the genre.   But it's Besson's direction that truly impresses.  Filled with interesting shots, perfect blocking and probing camerawork, Leon: The Professional is clearly superior to the typical Hollywood cookie cutter thriller.

Luc Besson's indie crime drama Leon: The Professional (1994) remains the French auteur's greatest picture by far. His focused and expressive French direction alongside cinematographer Thierry Arbogast's stunning, long held close-ups and creative wide shots during the action shootouts ensure that Leon is awe inspiring for future audiences forevermore. I must mention that although Luc Besson is a wretched creep as a man, he managed to use up all his creative powers to write and direct one of cinema's finest pictures.

Besson's writing is both creatively playful with funny dialogue and one liners, while also leaving you in despair at all the suffering and loneliness in Leon. His original story full of shocking brutality, clever wit, kind acts, and breathtaking twists result in Leon's memorable experience.

Eric Serra's score is riveting with gentle melodies and tight, anxiety inducing throbs of sound for the hail of bullets during the action sequences. Sylvie Landra's editing is sharp and tight, keeping Leon at a brisk 111 minutes that never feels long. Magali Guidasci's costumes are fun with Gary Oldman's white suit, Leon's all black hitman gear and vest, and of course, Natalie Portman's silly 90's kid outfits.

Jean Reno is so sensitive and subtle as the reserved assassin for hire Leon Montana. He's very playful and fatherly towards Mathilda Lando, saving Leon: The Professional's relationship with the young girl he saves from ever truly feeling gross. Natalie Portman is amazing for a child actress as the precocious child hitwoman protege Mathilda. She's funny, devastating, fearful, lonely, and a myriad of other emotions in a realistic flurry of acting prowess. 

Then, Gary Oldman is hilarious and terrifying as the crooked DEA agent Norman Stansfield. His campy drug addiction meets Oldman's gripping nightmare presence as the erratic and trigger happy Norman at his absolute scariest during the bathroom scene with Mathilda. Danny Aiello is excellent and enjoyable as the mob boss Tony with a nice rapport with Reno.

In short, Leon: The Professional is as fun and entertaining as action thriller films get, but Luc Besson's visionary direction and refreshing script keep Leon and Mathilda in your heart always.

Natalie Portman has a fantastic debut as a vengeful orphan; Jean Reno plays a surprisingly vulnerable and lonely assassin; but Gary Oldman is utterly brilliant in his performance as one of my favorite villains as a chaotic evil disguised as an orderly evil. The action is top-notched and gritty, with an emphasis on more of how the main character, Leon, acts as a contrast as a cold assassin on the job than in his quiet life. In September of '94 I was a senior in high school and never would have taken an interest in seeing a movie like The Professional.  This is probably a good thing, because for whatever reason, many of the movies I saw back then I've either watched too many times since, or simply forgotten about them.

I can now tick this off of the I-can't-believe-I've-never-seen-it list of movies and gratefully add it to the hey-that-was-pretty-good list.  
While the story itself has a certain timeless quality to it, there is something about the directions taken here that make it a very 90s movie.  I think if it'd been made earlier, it wouldn't have been as alive or as joyfully jarring as it is.  If it had been made much later, I think it would have gone further into the darker sides of the story and much of its innocence may have been sacrificed for shock value.
Natalie Portman went from unknown kid actress to star the second she pops up on screen.  She is magnetic and her accomplished performance could have carried this whole movie.  Now toss in the engaging turn by Jean Reno and a damn creepy (slightly over-the-top) villain from that chameleon Gary Oldman, and add a truly unique hitman story.  Boom.  Gold.  
In the hands of a more "known" studio or director the idea of a hitman who gets paired up with a twelve-year-old girl could have easily gone cutesy.  Luc Besson gives us plenty of cute and lots of warm-hearted laughter, but he's not afraid to keep this story grounded in a very adult world.  It's violent, it's vulgar, but it's also genuinely unnerving.  Portman's Matihlda is clearly not just "a cute kid" here.  She's been raised in an ugly environment of crime and poverty by loveless parents, with only her little brother and her imagination to turn to for any kind of genuine affection.  It's done a number on her.  Leon--Reno's loner hitman--has a tragic past as well that has left him in an almost mechanical state of being until Matilda comes along.  
There are many cliches that are avoided here, and those that sneak through are tolerable.  Much of the procedings are very far-fetched, but rarely bad enough to take me out of the moment.  All in all a very entertaining movie.  If you, like myself, missed it, track it down.  If you caught it before, I probably don't have to tell you to go catch it again.

Você com certeza já deve ter ouvido falar de León: The Professional (1994), aclamado filme de Luc Besson, alguma vez na sua vida. Se não, você já deve ter visto alguma citação do filme com a cara da Mathilda (Natalie Portman na sua versão antes do Shippuden) ou algum postzinho dela com suas roupas extravagantes ou fumando um cigarrinho enquanto descanda após sofrer os abusos de seus pais. Porém, The Professional é muito mais do que um filme cult adorado pelos indies, hipsters e seres esquisitos que habitam os confins do Tumblr de plantão. É um filme que fala sobre abuso infantil, fala sobre a solidão e fala sobre uma relação afetiva duvidosa, para uns apenas paternal e para as fãgirls ou para os punheteiros amorosa, entre uma garota de 12 anos (totalmente sexualizada no filme) e seu "mentor", ou chame ele do que você quiser, León (Jean Reno, em ótimo papel mesmo demonstrando um cara calado e meio ingênuo, em certos pontos), o cara que dá o nome ao filme e que por acaso é um assassino profissional que segue firme as suas regras. León aparentemente está na faixa dos 40 anos e vive sua vida monótona e tranquila como ninguém. Ele acorda cedo, faz seus exercícios matinais, bebe seus copos de leite (aparentemente ele não bebe outra coisa que não seja leite), cuida da sua plantinha e quando necessário sai para comprar mais caixas de leite. Porém, tudo muda quando seu vizinho é assassinado pelo oficial da narcóticos Stansfield (Gary Oldman, sempre ótimo o meu Garyzinho) e a filha dele, que nutre uma amizade com León, decide se vingar pela morte do seu irmão, um inocente menino de 4 anos que foi assassinado apenas por estar lá. A partir daí, Mathilda convence León de ensiná-la a matar e tenta dar um pouco de cor para a vida do assassino, mesmo que esse relutante sobre trazer a garota para seu perigoso mundo. Agora, me desculpem, mas se você por acaso shippa Mathilda e León eu tenho que te dar um certificado de doentão da porra, porque quem romantiza lolita pra mim no mínimo tem uns probleminhas bem sérios pra serem tratados. Mesmo com o filme hipersexualizando a menina e tornando ela mais "adulta", a criança está lá a todo momento, uma criança atormentada pelos traumas familiares e que desconta tudo no cigarro. O mínimo que se pode considerar de uma relação amorosa entre os dois protagonistas do longa pra mim é platônica, com Mathilda vendo em Léon a figura do Herói. Para mim, o ponto alto do filme é saber dosar entre ambos os personagens, construindo sua relação de dependência com maestria, mas não me desce esse papo de relação amorosa entre os dois. O Profissional é um ótimo filme de ação, daqueles que não são apenas tiros e superficiais. Vale a pena dar uma conferida, antes que seja morto por um atirador em treinamento.

cinegeek.de Luc Besson ist die kommerzielle französische Industrie. Er im Alleingang und dafür hasst ihn halb Frankreich. Fast vergisst man dabei seine kalten und traurigen Geschichten aus den 90ern. Professionelle Killerinnen, obsessive Taucher und Punks, die in den Schluchten der Pariser Metro leben, bevölkerten diese Filme. Die Vorbilder von Besson waren Comics und genauso sahen seine Filme aus. Der New Wave Stil der Zeit, in Frankreich fand man dafür den Begriff "Bande Dessinee". Luc Besson scheint ein Anhänger der Pygmalion Theorie zu sein, die besagt, dass jede Person durch Bildung transformiert werden kann. Dieser Glauben mit der Vorliebe Bessons für weibliche Killer, macht Leon - The Professional aus. Einen Fakt aber können wir dabei auf keinen Fall ignorieren: In Leon ist der weibliche Killer ein Mädchen von zwölf Jahren! Der ganze Film wird dabei unwahrscheinlich und von wundervoller Magie! Leon eröffnet mit einer sehr amerikanischen Sequenz (denn Besson verliess für diese Produktion zum ersten Mal Frankreich): Die Kamera fliegt über New York, taucht in die Wolkenkratzer-Schluchten und verharrt vor einer Tratoria. Darin sitzt der Mob Boss (Danny Aiello) und erwartet seinen "Cleaner", den Analphabetiker Leon (Jean Reno). Leon ist der Beste in seinem Fach des Tötens, scheint sich aber ansonsten auf dem Entwicklungsstand eines Kindes zu befinden. Wir erleben ihn bei der Arbeit, sehr effizient, wie er ein düsteres Inferno entfacht. Leon wird seine Nachbarin Matilda (Natalie Portman) adoptieren. Ein robustes Mädchen, dass die Strasse kennt. Sie sucht Schutz in Leons Apartment, nachdem der wahnsinnige Cop Stansfield (Gary Oldman) ihre Familie tötete. Im Gegenzug will Matilda Stansfield umbringen und dazu braucht sie Leons Ausbildung. Als Bezahlung verspricht sie, seine Wäsche zu waschen. Leon will nichts zu tun haben mit ihr, aber sie besteht darauf. Nach kurzer Zeit wirken beide wie ein altes Ehepaar, trotz des Altersunterschiedes von 30 Jahren. Obwohl der Film die dreckigsten Orte zeigt, die New York zu bieten hat und einige sehr gekonnte Shootouts, haben wir es im Herzen doch mit einer romantischen Fantasie zu tun. Besson hat keinen realistischen Thriller gemacht. Sein Film sieht aus wie ein europäisches Arthaus Werk - fast meint man, dass hier sei nicht Manhattan, sondern Paris! Leon - The Professional wahrt immer einen gewissen Abstand zum Geschehen: Wenn Matilda dem Killer das Lesen beibringt und er ihr zeigt, wie man sich exakt auf die Bewegungen eines "Probanden" einlässt, bevor man abdrückt... Ganz gleich, ob Leon von zehn oder hundert Polizisten umzingelt wird, er lässt sich einfach von der Decke eines Raumes fallen und erledigt sie alle. Genauso kann er sich fast telepathisch von einem Teil des Gebäudes zum nächsten bewegen. Der "Proband" glaubt ihn vor sich, doch längst steht Leon schon hinter ihm. Besson besitzt die Gabe, von seinen Action-Sequenzen immer wieder in sein Drama einzutauchen. Dabei hilft ihm die psychodelische Musik von Eric Serra, der alle Filme von Besson so herrlich untermalt (dringende Empfehlung: Einen Besson/Serra Soundtrack durchzuhören!). Die Liebesgeschichte von Leon und Matilda wirkt ganz natürlich und niemals obszön. Selbst in dem Moment, da sich beide ein Bett miteinander teilen, fiehl es mir nicht ein, daran Anstoss zu nehmen. Leon lebt mit der Seele eines Kindes, im Grunde noch unschuldig. Matilda dagegen hat bereits alles erlebt. Wenn sie Leon gesteht, dass sie ihn liebt, prustet er seine Milch aus vor Schreck. Dass Matilda noch ein Kind ist, spielt in Bessons Film keine Rolle. Wir müssen das als die Tragik seiner Geschichte akzeptieren. Ziehvater Leon kann ihr kein Leben bieten mit Schulbildung oder gleichaltrigen Freunden. Er schläft mit der Waffe im Schoss. Während Bessons Film und auch Leon wissen, dass dieses Leben falsch ist für ein junges Mädchen, nehmen wir es einfach so hin. Darin besteht Bessons Kunst der Inszenierung! dazu gibts die für uns aufregendsten Thriller mit Killer-Paaren.

In this film Jean Reno plays a hit man who takes a young girl (played by Natalie Portman) under his wing, and she then asks him to teach her the killing profession. The story is extremely straightforward and I probably could break down the entire film in only a few sentences. However the emotional impact of everything that is going on, and the interaction of the characters transcends the simplicity of the plot. There's something about Jean Reno's portrayal of Leon that is so enchanting. He plays the character with a childlike simplicity, because he is naive and seemingly knows very little apart from his job. Meanwhile Natalie Portman, as Mathilda, is almost cast into the adult role in their relationship because she has to teach him to read and how to interact with normal people. This isn't the only way that Luc Besson flips things from what you might expect, because we are also talking about a film where the protagonist is a professional killer. Meanwhile, (minor spoiler alert) the villain of the film is the leader of a team of DEA agents. This is another great acting performance offered by Gary Oldman. He is the master of creating unique characters with each performance. In this film, I love how he can have a smile on his face and yet you feel he might snap at any moment.

My only complaint about The Professional is that I wanted more time with the training of Mathilda. I really loved the interaction between the 2 lead characters and so I kind of wish we could see more of those moments where he is describing horrific things and she is accepting it without question. When the climax starts it seems to come out of left field and I don't like how unprepared Mathilda is in that moment. It's a minor complaint in what is otherwise a very good film. Besson captures some amazing shots, I particularly love some of the dramatic camera moves he uses, but he also knows when to leave the camera static and tell a story through the reactions of other characters. I am always fully invested in the plot of this movie and find myself clenching my teeth in excitement and anticipation in some of the more intense scenes. The Professional is one of those films that almost elicits a physical reaction from me in the final moments because I am so anxiously awaiting that moment of comeuppance for the villain. It's not exactly the most elaborate or involved script, and it probably won't knock most people off their feet, but I find it to be totally engaging, and I can highly recommend it to anyone. This might just be Besson's best film.

Review In A Nutshell:

Leon follows the relationship of a 12 year old girl and a hitman that was formed after the girl's family was massacred by corrupt drug enforcers.

Before coming into this film, I didn't know how deep Besson would go in exploring their relationship. I came in preparing that this would be a basic action-thriller that contains a human story in order to avoid seeming shallow. The film surprised me with its touching and unorthodox story. It never reaches to a point of feeling creepy or even unsympathetic as what Mathilda, the young girl, has went through was truly tragic and Besson understood how much this has affected her. The relationship between the two characters leans more towards the perspective of Mathilda and what Leon means to her. Leon is seen by both Mathilda and the audience as this guardian angel that is present to watch over her and protect her during this time of crisis. Mathilda has recently lost her family, therefore she would need some sort of way to express that grief but at the same time keep herself safe from the evil men who are after her. Leon is a man who has very little vices, aside from his ability to kill with very little sense of compassion. He wants to protect the girl as he has developed a connection with her, it's not particularly clear on what it is but it is understood that there is very little sense of romance for his feelings towards the girl. Mathilda has lost her sense of innocence, introducing her to a world of unjustified death and drugs that is being led by the hand of power-hungry men, and Leon is completely empathetic towards her urge to gain a sense of justice to the unnecessary murder that was committed, the death of her young and innocent brother.

Luc Besson delivers the film as both an action and dark comedic film. Though certain moments are shown as intense and with a sense of weight but there still lies a comedic aspect found on some of the characters. This dual tone kind of felt awkward on a couple of scenes, particularly during the film's first act but it is much better handled during the rest of the film. Besson was able to avoid the formulaic and cliché footsteps in action films, delivering something that is worth more investing, allowing for enjoyable returns during the future. I think it also due to the fact that Besson gives us a villain that we haven't truly seen before. It's a figure that I believe possesses similar qualities to strange villains like The Dark Knight's The Joker and Fight Club's Tyler Durden, but like the two, taking those qualities and deliver something fresh and exciting. I enjoyed the film's score that was composed by Eric Serra but I did feel its usage was a bit repetitive, sometimes almost to the point of beating me over the head with it. It sometimes felt like Besson didn't have faith in the film's plot, acting and photography in order to deliver the emotional quality that he was going for. Though this issue isn't something that is abundant, but one can feel its presence.

The acting in this film was astounding, with top performances from Reno, Portman and Oldman. One can see the fun and commitment they have given to their roles and showing a complete understanding with the director and his vision to the film. It is actually the intimate scenes between Portman and Reno that truly carry this film, having the audience to be truly invested with their relationship and completely sympathising/empathising with the two characters. There are two brilliant scenes that I want to point out as there is something about it that always brings grin on my face when I think about it, and it's the ones concerning the two lead character's knowledge and love of film. When Leon goes to watch Singin' in the Rain or when both play a game in guessing the iconic figures of American cinema/culture. Oldman didn't need other actors in order for us to feel his presence, as the quirkiness and oddities in his character during solo moments are simply fun to watch. He doesn't want us to completely understand and decipher the character, as the less we could empathise with his intentions the more frightening he comes off as.

Leon: The Professional is an example of an action thriller that also delivers a powerful human relationship that explores the importance of growth, love and loss. Though it did have minor tonal issues and repetitive qualities in its use of the musical score, it's still a film that one shouldn't avoid or pass when the opportunity to watch it arises.

Leon: The Professional is clearly an amalgamation of everything that Luc Besson has done in the past. It takes the best elements from all his works and none of the worst. The intro scene is very much a neo-noir style sequence, With an intense focus on the black lenses in Leone "Leon" Montana's glasses and the smoke that stems from the cigarettes, the sequence feels very neo-noir. This scene is so focused on a stylistic use of close cinematography that it illuminates a natural sense of beauty in everything and turns it all into relevant imagery. But what's more impressive proves to be how the imagery serves as a driving force behind the narrative. Leon: The Professional is very rich on characterization. The three central characters in the story are given an immediate foreshadowing of what unfolds over the course of the narrative, with Leone "Leon" Montana showing an emotionless lack of remorse in the face of his professional approach to his physical work, Norman Stansfield as a suit whose true nature as an unhinged psychotic leaks into his delusion that he can physically sniff out a lie, and Mathilda whose short legs dangle over the stairwell in her colourful socks as the camera pans up to her face and reveals her smoking a cigarette. Through no dialogue whatsoever, Leon: The Professional is able to use the least imagery to explain the most about its characters, finally putting Luc Besson's keen eye for imagery to the best extent of work.
The fact that Leon: The Professional actively makes an attempt to put depth into the life of a hitman is a concept I never expected anyone to really succeed in, let alone Luc Besson whose films have a tendency to be about nothing. He has never before made a film which has so much depth and character to it, and for a man like him to take such stereotypically shallow subject matter and transcend it to an all new level is a truly remarkable feat. His writing work is tenacious because he truly understands the minds and hearts of the characters he is creating, bringing them to life long before the actors have a chance the embrace the roles.
In an innovative spin on the cinema du look style Luc Besson has popularized, Leon: The Professional makes use of the same clever integration of varying class themes and effectively emphatic cinematography, while diverting the sense of energy into a slow-burning narrative and neutralizing the sense of colour to embody a drier and grittier neo-noir feeling. The story takes time to develop the relationship between Leon and Mathilda very slowly, but the story is so remarkably engaging that it is easy to forget. Occasionally there is a sense that the film has such huge ambitions that it cannot develop everything to the same insightful extent that it does with its most major themes, but the true extent of Luc Besson's work reaches the point where it it able to go back on Luc Besson's pre-established stylish elements and take a step forward into a new realm of filmmaking at the same time. It is truly his finest work to date with a narrative that is unforgettable.
The overall mood of the film is remarkable. There is a sporadic comedic touch to lighten the mood at times, but the story is far from comedic. You would think on the surface that the story about a man training a 12 year old to become an assassin would have some kind of cheesy gimmick to it, but in actuality Luc Besson takes it remarkably seriously without ever looking back. Because of this, the slow-burning nature of the film feels constantly intense which grips the viewer in a combination of tenacious thrills and tear-jerking emotional drama. It's hard not to feel anything from watching Leon: The Professional as viewers are truly in the presence of an absolute cinematic classic.
And the visual experience of the film is magnificent. Playing off the aforementioned intro sequence which drives everything with mere imagery, Leon: The Professional maintains this feeling so consistently for the entire film. In achieving this, the cinematography plays with a series of brilliantly atmospheric angles that defy any American cinematic convention and always capture the mood of every scene with ideal scale and atmosphere. And the way that the action in the film integrates into all this is strong because it follows the hitman subject matter of the film into being more focused on realism than glamourization, even though the cinema du look style ensures that everything has glamour to it either way. It is far from exploitational as the manner it is staged in proves consistently proves to fit in with the accurately. It has some moments of being bloody or explosive, but it never defies the intricate nature of the story as a small scaled thriller, making the most of its limited assortment of locations without attempting to go over the top with it all.
The classical musical score is also a brilliant element in Leon: The Professional as it is a central element of the cinema du look style and also a brilliant reflection of the different extents of sophistication maintained by each character in one way or another.
But the true extent of brilliance in these characters can very largely be credited to the remarkable talents of the cast.
Jean Reno delivers the single greatest performance of his career as the titular cleaner in Leon: The Professional. Jean Reno has the innocent smile of a child at times and the expression of a confused one at others, but when he puts on his glasses he buries himself into his professionalism. This is clearly where all his thinking is focused into, and that becomes the path to an incredibly interesting character. The man's ability to turn Leon's lack of formal education into a signifier of his simplistic view of the world while balancing it with an unmatched intelligence for his role as a "cleaner". Jean Reno actually has few lines in the film because he doesn't mess around, he is always directly to the point as he has nothing to say which is not of direct relevance. And the way he speaks is very interesting. Leon does not impose his status as a hitman onto Mathilda as a form of condescension, and this plays multiple roles in the narrative. Among them is the notion that his view of the world does not rate one person above another as he has to view everyone equally within his professional ideology and that he is well aware of how important Mathilda is to him for what she can do that he cannot. Jean Reno sticks to a largely monotonous line delivery in Leon: The Professional because his character has to learn to feel as the story goes on, but he keeps it remarkably subtle the whole time and evokes a sense of sophistication through his natural French accent. Jean Reno is never explicit in his performance, he delivers a remarkably restrained effort in which he can say so much through his simple facial expressions and develop his character so much in the process. Jean Reno creates such a complex character out of Leone "Leon" Montana which is beyond expectation and too beautiful to condense into any number of words, so I'll simplify it by saying it is perhaps the greatest performance given by any male actor in a Luc Besson film ever.
And since Luc Besson has a remarkable talent for creating meaningful female characters, it is beautiful that one was given to Natalie Portman in her debut performance. The actress who went on to win an Academy Award sixteen years after her performance and went through numerous high profile films along the way including the Star Wars prequel trilogy delivers one of the greatest performances of any child actor in history in Leon: The Professional. That's a very big claim to make, but for anyone who has seen Natalie Portman's performance, there is no denying the truth.  Though both Jean Reno and Gary Oldman are the more experienced actors of the cast and Natalie Portman has credited them with teaching her much about acting, her character Mathilda takes a powerful stand in bringing the viewers' emotions into the experience. As Leon is a character viewers can never fully understand considering the mystery surrounding him, Mathilda is the one to for viewers to find a pathway into the film through. For a twelve year old girl, Mathilda is such a remarkably complex and beautiful character. Clearly an extension on Luc Besson's titular creation in La Femme Nikita, Mathilda is arguably the most important character in the story. As sweet as the lollipop she holds during her first scenes in the film, Natalie Portman has a remarkably natural childish spirit about her. And yet she contrasts it with a remarkable level of grit to represent her shattered innocence. This grit is something she develops into a sense of professionalism as she turns into a cleaner herself, and this is truly remarkable because the idea of a child assassin sounds like a ridiculous concept on the surface. But with Natalie Portman in a performance I feel is ultimately the greatest of her career, the reality is all too powerful to ignore. Natalie Portman is made to cry at multiple points in the film, but it never feels like a child throwing a tantrum. It is the sight of a human being embracing emotional pain that she cannot deny, and it reflects just how deeply she delves into the character. Her chemistry with Jean Reno proves them to be of at bare minimum equal levels of talent, ensuring that they are both able to help each other develop. Natalie Portman delivers a groundbreaking performance which is remarkable to call a debut, and something which is truly of Academy Award calibre. 
Gary Oldman is also an unforgettable presence. Even with only a small handful of scenes, Gary Oldman delivers one of the finest performances of his career. With an amazing talent for playing villains, Gary Oldman reaches the endeavour of this talent in Leon: The Professional by turning Norman Stansfield into an antagonist called by many critics one of cinema's greatest villains. The psychotic sadism lies predominantly in his physicality for the earlier parts of the film because much of his line delivery is realistically sociopathic and monotonous, while the insanity rests on what he can do physically. Every inch of the man's physical movements is unhinged, whether it is subtle or explicit. And the way that the camera captures every inch of Gary Oldman's physical performance is brutal. Gary Oldman maintains a restrained edge of sophistication in his part which breaks down more and more as he oscillates between that and periods of drug enhanced madness. Gary Oldman seems like a passionately violent man in Leon: The Professional, and he is so lost in the performance that it is almost disturbing. Norman Stansfield is clearly another character in Leon: The Professional which serves as one of Luc Besson's finest creations. 
Danny Aiello is also a most-welcome presence. Serving as perhaps the most recognizable American actor in the film upon its release in 1994, Danny Aiello's small supporting role is great because of how he interacts with Jean Reno. Through his most simple interactions with the man, Tony is simply an errand boy to a cleaner. He is a messenger, and yet Danny Aiello's approach to Jean Reno is so much more. With a complete understanding of the character Leon in a way that audiences never will, Tony interacts with Leon with a patiently direct approach to addressing the man. He is essentially a father figure to Leon, and he brings such a friendly presence to the film where he never conveys any sense of ulterior motives. Danny Aiello's small part in the story is a brilliant touch.

So Leon: The Professional is an exceedingly ambitious film and nothing short of a masterpiece, putting unprecedented depth into the life of a hitman and his 12 year old female protege through Luc Besson's most exceptionally deep writing talents and keen eye for remarkable imagery combined with rich atmosphere and revolutionary acting.

Oh, the days when Luc Besson was good. Yes, before dumbing down his original vision of graphic violence and great characters with such awful films as The Transporter, Colombiana, and Starshit Troopers, this French director was actually incredibly good. Sure, even some of his more critically lauded and publically beloved movies such as Taken and The Fifth Element are slightly overrated, but who cares? The guy knows how to direct an action sequence. Unlike shit directors like Michael Bay or John Moore, he understands that even fight scenes require scripting and careful planning, and you can't just choreograph your sequences by sticking two tin cans in a blender. But if it weren't for the poetic and human touch that he brings to his films, it would all be for naught. In short, The Professional is a beautiful and gripping story about a relationship between a hitman and his young apprentice, interspersed between scenes of exceedingly graphic deaths. Is it for the weak-stomached? No. But it is for people who are serious about film.

The Professional stars Jean Reno as Leon, a French hitman living in New York who is (as the title would suggest) a fucking pro at what he does. This is established in the opening sequence, a spectacular meta-feat that combines biting wit and absolutely jaw-dropping action into one massive melting pot that not only entertains, but helps define the character before the audience even sees him. But after a chance encounter with a 12-year-old girl in the apartment next to him (and the cringeworthy deaths of her family members at the hands of a maniacal police officer), Leon is forced to start playing a father figure. There are weird undertones of pedophilia here, which are to be expected: It's a movie about a grown man taking care of a little girl, so there are sure to be some accusations of that. And it's true that the girl (played by Natalie Portman in her breakout role) expresses her feelings for Leon constantly. But it was never for show or cheap thrills for the audience... seriously, that's sick. It's just because she had lost her whole family, and needed someone to hold on to. She doesn't quite understand what the things she says mean, but she knows enough to get by. And props to Leon for never even thinking about taking the bait. Good man. 

Portman pretty much sets the standard for all child actors with her remarkable and completely unforgettable performance in this film, turning her character into more than just a weird juxtaposition. Watching this movie, I could tell that the creators of Kick-Ass clearly saw something in her character and later ripped her off, turning her into Hit Girl. But unlike that bland and rote mess of a movie, The Professional gives its characters some life. Not only does Portman shine, but Leon's quiet, assured personality lets on more about him than he'd like to. They are also helped along by Gary Oldman, a real chameleon of film, who delivers a frightening and goosebump-inducing performance as the aforementioned amoral police officer who is involved in dozens of corrupt dealings, the least of which being his cold-blooded murder of Portman's family. His transformation into this absolutely terrifying character ranks as one of the best supporting performances of all time, and he nails every scene he's in, from his suitably creepy neck-cracking to his panicked scream of "EVERYONE!!!" The man is amazing.

This film's script is also fantastic, giving us such quotable lines as the one that led off this review, not to mention "I don't have time for this MICKEY MOUSE BULLSHIT!" and  "Never in the face." Every line of dialogue is worthy of being iconic, but if I had to choose, I'd say that Leon's code of ethics has to be the best part of the film: "No women, no kids. That's the rules." His character is given more depth than almost any other badass contract-killer in film, and although that's not saying much, it's still a feat. You care about him for every second of the movie, because there's something about him that sets him apart from the other action stars that we've seen shoot up buildings countless times over. His training scenes with Portman should put a smile on your face, and when the final sequence rolls around, you'll be utterly enthralled. Truly one of the best-scripted, best-acted characters ever created.

Final Score for Leon: The Professional: 9/10 stars. An all-around impressive movie that hits hard from dramatic and visceral standpoints, giving us characters we care about, a straightforward story that delivers the thrills, and three spectacular performances. My problems with this movie are few, but I would say that it goes on a tad too long and that the action sequence at the end feels somewhat bludgeoning. Still, it's hard to argue with a movie this assured about what it is trying to do. If you can't handle the gore, don't watch the film. But for both strong-stomached fans of drama and action junkies alike, The Professional will keep you at the edge of your seat.

Review In A Nutshell:

Leon follows the relationship of a 12 year old girl and a hitman that was formed after the girl's family was massacred by corrupt drug enforcers.

Before coming into this film, I didn't know how deep Besson would go in exploring their relationship. I came in preparing that this would be a basic action-thriller that contains a human story in order to avoid seeming shallow. The film surprised me with its touching and unorthodox story. It never reaches to a point of feeling creepy or even unsympathetic as what Mathilda, the young girl, has went through was truly tragic and Besson understood how much this has affected her. The relationship between the two characters leans more towards the perspective of Mathilda and what Leon means to her. Leon is seen by both Mathilda and the audience as this guardian angel that is present to watch over her and protect her during this time of crisis. Mathilda has recently lost her family, therefore she would need some sort of way to express that grief but at the same time keep herself safe from the evil men who are after her. Leon is a man who has very little vices, aside from his ability to kill with very little sense of compassion. He wants to protect the girl as he has developed a connection with her, it's not particularly clear on what it is but it is understood that there is very little sense of romance for his feelings towards the girl. Mathilda has lost her sense of innocence, introducing her to a world of unjustified death and drugs that is being led by the hand of power-hungry men, and Leon is completely empathetic towards her urge to gain a sense of justice to the unnecessary murder that was committed, the death of her young and innocent brother.

Luc Besson delivers the film as both an action and dark comedic film. Though certain moments are shown as intense and with a sense of weight but there still lies a comedic aspect found on some of the characters. This dual tone kind of felt awkward on a couple of scenes, particularly during the film's first act but it is much better handled during the rest of the film. Besson was able to avoid the formulaic and clichÃ (C) footsteps in action films, delivering something that is worth more investing, allowing for enjoyable returns during the future. I think it also due to the fact that Besson gives us a villain that we haven't truly seen before. It's a figure that I believe possesses similar qualities to strange villains like The Dark Knight's The Joker and Fight Club's Tyler Durden, but like the two, taking those qualities and deliver something fresh and exciting. I enjoyed the film's score that was composed by Eric Serra but I did feel its usage was a bit repetitive, sometimes almost to the point of beating me over the head with it. It sometimes felt like Besson didn't have faith in the film's plot, acting and photography in order to deliver the emotional quality that he was going for. Though this issue isn't something that is abundant, but one can feel its presence.

The acting in this film was astounding, with top performances from Reno, Portman and Oldman. One can see the fun and commitment they have given to their roles and showing a complete understanding with the director and his vision to the film. It is actually the intimate scenes between Portman and Reno that truly carry this film, having the audience to be truly invested with their relationship and completely sympathising/empathising with the two characters. There are two brilliant scenes that I want to point out as there is something about it that always brings grin on my face when I think about it, and it's the ones concerning the two lead character's knowledge and love of film. When Leon goes to watch Singin' in the Rain or when both play a game in guessing the iconic figures of American cinema/culture. Oldman didn't need other actors in order for us to feel his presence, as the quirkiness and oddities in his character during solo moments are simply fun to watch. He doesn't want us to completely understand and decipher the character, as the less we could empathise with his intentions the more frightening he comes off as.

Leon: The Professional is an example of an action thriller that also delivers a powerful human relationship that explores the importance of growth, love and loss. Though it did have minor tonal issues and repetitive qualities in its use of the musical score, it's still a film that one shouldn't avoid or pass when the opportunity to watch it arises.

Obra maestra de la mano del gran director francés Luc Besson. Formidable filme hecho en Francia que muestra el lado violento del New York de inicios de los 80s. Este filme no solo es el impresionante debut de Natalie Portman con escasos 11 años cuando inició la filmación, sino que sirvió para introducir a Jean Reno, gran actor francés, a la audiencia americana, y además terminó de consolidar la imagen de Gary Oldman como uno de los grandes villanos del cine de los 90s, que ya había se había hecho notar en su participación en "JFK" interpretando a uno de los asesinos más famosos de la historia moderna, y además había encarnado al mismísimo príncipe de la oscuridad en "Bram Stoker's Dracula", y aquí como el desquiciado Stansfield (que como dato curioso hace referencias a Beethoven, que sería un personaje que interpretaría posteriormente), es el perfecto oponente para un formidable Leon (Reno) que durante el filme te van preparando ya que sabes que cuando esos dos titanes se encuentren en el mismo sitio, las cosas se pondrán feas. Luc Besson logran acertadamente desarrollar a la pareja dispareja de Leon y Mathilda, pudiendo llegar a saber qué pasa por la mente de ambos personajes y como cada uno causa cambios importantes en las personalidades de ambos y su forma de ver la vida.
